Biography

I am a senior at the University of Washington, and a fellow at the International Policy Institute for Cybersecurity. I've had the opportunity to study Mandarin in Beijing as a FLAS Fellow where I made friends with cab drivers. I'm passionate about Jekyll, an open-source static site generator that first got me interested in web development. I'm interested in Go and Rust, but enjoy most of my time working with Ruby. I also like to play with Serpent to explore ethereum.

I'm usually at the Seattle Bouldering Project socializing, or reading . When I'm not doing homework, I enjoy running around Seattle.

Education

University of Washington

Seattle, Washington — International Studies ‘18

My research interests include the economics of information security, peer-to-peer network systems, cryptographic protocols, and digital civil liberties. I also had the experience living in China and am curious about how public policy effect freedom online. I'm also interested in the development of the next generation programming languages, such as Rust, for better security and performance.

I'm also a editor at the Jackson School Journal for International Studies, where I collaborate with a student and faculty team to publish peer-reviewed student work.

International Community School

Kirkland, Washington

Skills

As I said, I write software. I write in Go, UNIX/GNU via Bash, JavaScript, Ruby, HTML, CSS daily, and store it all in git. I’m proficient in a bunch of other languages and love to learn new ones, but I don’t use them regularly. I learned how to program using Java and PHP, so I would say I know them fairly well.

Jekyll and Goji (a Go library) are my two favourite tools for website creation. My static sites are tossed behind nginx, because I believe in good memory practices.

I’m concise, task-oriented, and am a lover of IRC/IM for communicating with team members. I’m a big believer in asynchronous communication for discussion and code review beyond initial planning stages. I like a good challenge.

Work Experience

Summer Intern

C2FO - Innovation Lab, Seattle, WA

Summer, 2017

Exploring new technologies to make supply-chain financing more efficient, secure, and prosperous. Check out the research I did on the Quorum blockchain and Rust at the Intern Blog I started. More to come... github.com →

Research Fellow

Microsoft Corp. and the University of Washington

Spring, 2017

I worked closely with Microsoft Security, researching cyberattack attribution. Our 50 page report proposes an international, private-sector organization tasked with attributing major state-sponsored cyber attacks. We presented our findings Microsft's Redmond campus. In August, we will brief congressional staff on the major themes of the report.

Microsoft Research →

Business Operations

BitTrust

2015 - Current

Part of the three-person team that developed the standard web app for Bitcoin company ratings. Bittrust.org aggregates user reviews of Bitcoin services because we believe using cyptocurrencies should be reliable and easy. We're continually working to improve the website, integrating user authentication and providing better content with filters. Expect a redesign soon. The BitTrust Blog analyzes developments in the cryptocurrency world. BitTrust.org →

Intern

King County Bar Association

2016 - 2017

I worked as a liaison for attorneys at KCBA’s 34 Neighborhood Legal Clinics and to help the KCBA deliver inclusive legal services in the greater Seattle region.

King County Bar Association.

Route Setter

University of Washington Crags Climbing Gym, Seattle, WA

2015 - Current

As a route setter for the intramurial climbing center at UW, I contribute to a vibrant climbing community by providing challenging, acrobatic climbing routes. My favorite holds are

Research and Publications

“Flooding the Gates: An overview of China’s M&A in Europe” Henry M. Jackson School of International Studies. (2017). Jackson School Journal of International Studies.
